DOC.HEAD: Eighteen State Legislatures Targeted by Democrats
DOC.TEXT: Statehouse races in 18 states will be targeted next year by Democrats who hope to control state legislatures when congressional districts are redrawn for the 1990s. Democrats will try to raise $3 million to help candidates for the legislatures in those states next year, Tim Dickson, who heads the party's Project 500 program, said Tuesday. Democrats are particularly concerned with states likely to gain or lose congressional districts as a result of population shifts that will come to light in the 1990 census. They are also focusing on states where the majority's grip in the state legislature is tenuous. The targeted states are Arizona, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Texas, Virginia, Washington and Wisconsin. Democrats now control 36 state Houses and 32 state Senates, while Republicans control 12 Houses and 17 Senates. They share power in Indiana's House; Nebraska has a nonpartisan bicameral legislature.
DOC.HEAD: Sears, Government Settle Insulation Ads Complaint
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck & Co. has agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to settle a dispute with the government over insulation ads, the Federal Trade Commission said. The FTC said Sears or its representatives had failed to include details on the insulation's heat resistance when it promoted the thickness and price of the product. The ads ran within the last five years. Chicago-based Sears has agreed to create an advertisement designed to educate consumers about home insulation, especially the importance of having heat-resistance information when making a purchase, the FTC said Tuesday. ``The violations were technical in nature and did not result in any consumer complaints,'' Sears spokesman Gordon Jones said. ``There was no misrepresentation or deception involved.'' The settlement must be approved by a federal judge in Washington. The FTC said the consent decree does not constitute admission of a law violation. The penalty is paid to the government, not consumers.
DOC.HEAD: Government Upgrades Beretta Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration says it's upgrading an investigation of a possible steering deficiency in the 1988 Chevrolet Beretta. The agency also said Tuesday it was beginning probes of reported explosions in the heating systems of Coachmen Industries recreational vehicles and of cruise control failures in the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable. The agency said it was stepping up its Beretta probe from a preliminary evaluation, which involves mostly paperwork, to an engineering analysis, in which the possibly defective parts are examined. Such investigations can lead to recalls or can be dismissed if engineers decide there is no widespread safety problem.
